Univariate Cox Proportional Hazards Fit via survival::coxph()

Source: R/Rinternal.R
univariate_cox.Rd

Fits a single-predictor Cox proportional hazards model against the null (no covariates) using survival::coxph(), returning the coefficient estimate, standard error, Wald test, likelihood ratio test statistics, and BIC-based model comparison quantities.

Arguments

y

Response data: either an n × 2 numeric matrix with columns (time, status), or a list of two numeric vectors: (time, status).

x

Numeric vector of length n: covariate values.

offset

Optional numeric vector of length n, or scalar: offset term in the linear predictor. If scalar, it is expanded.

ties

Character string: method for handling tied event times, either "efron" (default) or "breslow".

Value

A list with elements:

  • beta: Estimated regression coefficient for x.

  • se: Standard error of beta.

  • wald_z: Wald test statistic.

  • wald_p: Wald test p-value.

  • logLik1: Partial log-likelihood of single-variable model.

  • logLik0: Partial log-likelihood of null model.

  • LRT: Likelihood ratio statistic \(2(\ell_1 - \ell_0)\).

  • LRT_p: Likelihood ratio test p-value (chi-square with df=1).

  • BIC1: BIC of single-variable model (based on partial likelihood).

  • BIC0: BIC of null model (based on partial likelihood).

  • deltaBIC: Difference \(\mathrm{BIC}_1 - \mathrm{BIC}_0\) (negative favors variable model).

  • twoLogBF: Approximate \(2 \log BF_{1,0} \approx \mathrm{BIC}_0 - \mathrm{BIC}_1\).

  • ties: Ties handling method used.

  • has_offset: Logical indicating if an offset was provided.

Details

This function wraps survival::coxph() for univariate fits, with an optional offset term and choice of ties handling. For each predictor, it fits: $$\mathrm{Surv}(time, status) \sim x + \mathrm{offset}$$ and compares it to the null model $$\mathrm{Surv}(time, status) \sim 1 + \mathrm{offset}.$$

Extracts the slope coefficient, standard error, and Wald test p-value (from summary.coxph()), as well as the partial log-likelihoods, BIC values, likelihood ratio test (LRT), and the BIC-based approximation to the Bayes factor: $$2 \log BF_{1,0} \approx \mathrm{BIC}_0 - \mathrm{BIC}_1.$$
